cell.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: Deutsche Levante-Linie.
div.p: Mail and Passenger Steamships. EXPECTED AT ALEXANDRIA.
S.S. Lesbos July 20 from Antwerp.
S.S. Androos July 20 from Hamburg bound for Beyrout.
S.S. Lemnos July 31 from Hamburg bound for Beyrout.
For tariff and particulars apply to ADOLPHE STROSS, Alexandria, Agent.

div.p: Restaurant and Sleeping Cars on Luxor trains:
A Restaurant car and a sleeping car are attached to the 8 p.m. train from Cairo every Monday, Wednesday and Saturday and to the 5.30 p.m. train from Luxor every Tuesday, Thursday and Sunday.

Railway and Sleeping Car tickets can be obtained any number of days ahead at the office of the International Sleeping Car Company in Cairo Station. 1st class Cairo-Luxor P.T. 200. Sleeping Car supplement P.T. 75.

div.head: SUDAN GOVERNMENT RAILWAYS.
div.p: CAIRO-KHARTOUM SUMMER MAIL SERVICE.--SUMMER TIME-TABLE 1906.
Commencing from 1st of April, 1906, until further notice

‡Sleeping and Dining Cars. — During the month of April Sleeping and Dining Care trains leave Cairo for Luxor on Wednesdays, Mondays and Saturdays at 6.30 p.m. and Luxor for Cairo on Sundays, Tuesdays and Thursdays at 6.30 p.m.

From 1st of May 1908, these trains will be suppressed, but Dining and Sleeping Care will be attached to the ordinary night Tains from Cairo and Luxor three times a week, on the same above mentioned days. 14-6-907

div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.p: 26848 Alexandria & Cairo. 4-12 906

THE GREATEST care should be taken in what we ent and drink, yet we are too often indifferent and careless, notwithstanding health depends on what we eat and drink. In regard to drink nothing but the best should he taken. It costs us more than the indifferent quality, if people would only ask for what they know is the best Old Scott Whisky is the most wholesome beverage yet known Mackie's Scotch Whisky gives an undoubted gusrantee to those who are not judges of quality.

div.head: Sudan Express Mail Service
div.p: Three days to Khartoum

By KHEDIVIAL MAIL EXPRESS S.S. "PRINCE ABBAS" and "EL KAHIRA" and SUDAN GOVERNMENT RAILWAYS "Trains de Luxe." DEPARTURES from SUEZ POCK8 every WEDNES DAY 5 p.m. after arrival of 11 a.m. Train from Cairo, with Through Carriages to alongside 'steamer. Special Sudan Government Train de Luxe with Sleeping and Dining Cars, awaits steamer's arrival at PORT SUDAN, FRIDAY EVENINGS, arriving KHARTOUM 8 p.m. SATURDAYS. RETURNING from KHARTOUM, the Special Train leaves TUESDAYS 9.15 p.m. arriving alongside steamer at PORT SUDAN WEDNESDAY EVEN. INGS. Steamer is timed to reach SUEZ SATURDAYS, to connect with 5.40 p.m. train to Cairo. Further particulars may be obtained from any of KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE'S Agencies or from Principal Tourist Agencies by whom Circular Tickets are issued to Khartoum by the Nile, returning by Red Sea Express Service or Vice-Versa.

Thursday, January 23rd, 1908

div.head: Egypt and the Sudan
div.p: Commenting upon Sir Eldon Gorst's visit to the Sudan the Standard" says : Sir Eldon Gorst, who is returning to Cairo after bis brief tour of inspection in the Sudan, bas bad an opportunity of seeing something of the latest developments of that interesting territory. It is perhaps needless to say that the high political significance attributed to the visit by the anti-English journalists of Cairo exists only in the imagination of those ingenious persons. These astute critics, who bave lately been endeavouring to persuade their readers that the Sudan is a crushing and onprofitable burden upon Egypt, have been suggesting that Sir Eldon will inaugurate an ora of drastic economies for the upper country. Some of them even went so far as to hint that in this enterprise the British Consul-General was to receive the active assistance of the Under Secretary for the Colonies, and that the two statesmen would have an opportunity of conferring on these matters on the Upper Nile. Nothing of course could be more ridiculous. Neither Egypt nor the Sudan comes, in the smallest de ree, within the Under-Secretary's "sphere of influence." At Khartum Mr. Winston Churchill was received with the courtesy which in that pleasant and hospitable capital is often extended even to less distinguished guests; but his visit had no more official oberacter than that of any other traveller who happened to be passing through on his way down from the equatorial regions, and both Mr. Churchill and his hosts took care to do nothing which could lead to misconception on this point. As a fact, the Under Secretary for the Colonies bad goitted Khartum before Sir Eldon Gorst had left Cairo ; and though they passed one another on the journey they could certainly have had no facilities, even if such had been sought, for the discussion of political affairs Apart from this myth, there is no reason to suppose that any immediate change in Sudan policy is contemplated or any serious revolution in the relations, financial and orber, which link the Anglo-Egyptian condominium to the Khedivial Government. The situation, so ably sum. marised in the last of Lord Cromer's great series of Reports, is not for the present likely to be modified in its main lines. But bere, as elsewbere, Sir Eldon Gorst has been anxious to render bimself familiar with all the details of administration, not so much with the idea of correcting the work of his predecessor as of extending and amplifying it, and adapting it where necessary to exigencies which were not contemplated during the years when Lord Cromer was rebuilding the fabric of orderly administration throughout the Nile Valley. In the Sudan, even more than in Egypt, the problem is one of developing by administiative means the resources of the country That the vast territory, in spite of its tracts of arid waste and inbospitable desert, contains the possibililies of immense agricultural wealth is the assured belief of all who know something about it. Irrigation; population, and communication are its three prime requisites. Next, of course, after that repression of rapine and violence which the Anglo-Egyptian arins have secured. The first and second of thee two great needs cannot be supplied, other difficulties apart, until progress has been made with the third. The Sudan, like the Britain of the Roman poet, has been penitus toto divisum ab urbe : too long cut oft from the stream of the world's commerce, and accessible only by the long, narrow thoroughfare that leads from the Mediterranean by the Nile sud over the cataracts and through the desert. By that difficult and devious track, on the decks of sailing boats and river steamers, and on the backs of camels, such heavy articles as machinery and building plant have been conveyed with infinite labour into the heart of tropical Africa. But for modern commeree the route is far too slow and too costly. From the beginning of our occupation of the terrirory it has been seen that the Sudan, if it is to make full use of its agricultural capacities, must be placed in direct communication with the Red Sea. During the last year and a half this aim has been achieved. The railways from the Atbara, near Berber, to Port Sudan, few miles from Snakin, is the worthy complement of the work of Lord Kitcbener and Sir Percy Girvuard when they carried the line across the desert from Wady Halfe, and so placed Khurtum in contact with Europe and the Nile Delta From the mercantile point Tof view, the Port Sudan railway, is even more valuable. Sir Eldon Gorst, whose tour in. cluded a trip over the new line and an ex amination of its outlet, can bardly fail to bave been surprised at wbat be saw. In the sbort space of two years and a half he will have found that the engiveers of the Sudan Government have bridged the old caravan route to the sea by a railway, on which one can travel in all the height of modern luxury ; and at the terwious they have laid something more than the foundation of a first-rate modern port and trading town on what thirty years ago was a stretch of uninbabited foreshore. At Port Sydan tbe Consul General saw the plans of fiue streets, squares, public buildingo; be saw in actual being quays, warehouse, steam cranes, coal lifting machinery-all the appliances of brisk and enterprising trade. Port Sudan, with its fine harbour and its open channel, navigable at all hours and in all tides, may become one of the notable commercial entrepots of the world. Sooner or later it seems inevitable that the trade of North Eyoatorial Africa must flow through its gates. Meanwhile, it has brought the Sudan into almost startling coutignity with the main centres of the world's industry and population. A passenger travelling by this route can reach Khartum eight days after leaving London, without suffering the smallest discomfort or inconvenience en route ; a load of cotton, grown on the Sudan plantation, can be raileal to the Red Sea and shipped to the docks at Salford without breaking bulk and in a space of time which will compare very favourably with the transit from most other centres for the supply of the fibre. By an audacious flank attack, the isolation of Central Africa has at length been broken down, and the results of the movement, though they may not be realised so quickly with its leaders anticipate, must oveatually be remarkable.

div.head: Local and General
div.p: A military band will play every Thursday at the Grand Continental Hotel.
A telegram from Djeddah announced 23 deaths there from cholera The "Assouan" has sailed 1,423 Egyptians.
Thirty four tons of Egyptian and three and half tous Abyssinian ivory have arrived in London for the quarterly sales, which commence on the 28th instant The Imperial Perrote.
The Imperial Pierrots are to give an entertainment in the Recreation Rooms, Kasr el Nil Barracks, on Friday evening next, Colonel Markham having kindly placed the rooms at their disposal.

The bridge which is in course of construction over the Blue Nile between Khartoum and Khartoum North is making exellent progress, and it is expected that the masonry will be visible above the water in a few weeks time.

The services at St Mary's Church, Kasr-elDoubara, on Sunday next will be as follows: 8 am. Holy Communion 10. 30. a m. Mattins and Sertion, 6 pm. Evensong.be Rev. P. A Braithwaite, D.D., LL D, Rector, will conduct the services.

The issue of the remaining bonds of the Agricultural Bank of Egypt, which, we understand, has recently taken place, will afford this institution a means of removing onerous restrictions, which it bad to pursue owing to s lack of integral funds. This will now menn a contingence of the outflow of small loans, E which under present conditions will certainly be readily paght after by the fellaheen pipoc lation of Egypt.

A new departure was made at the Cuorban. Bairam ceremony in the Mirassin Kiosk, at Yildiz, on Wednesday, when for the first time since his session the Sultan allowed himselt to be photographed. After accepting the bomage of all the Ministers, functionaries, IG and notables, the Sultan received the con gratulations of the Ambassadors. His Majesty who appeared to be in very good bralth, obatted brightly with the latter for over an hour, and laughingly mentioned that he had four pbotographie cameras at work all througb the ceremony taking anap sbots, but be feared they would prove a failure as the light was poor.

The semi-fuel of the Big Unit Shield Was played at the Khedivial Sporting Club on Wednesday afternoon, the coutesting teams N being the King Owu Scottish Borderers v. these 60 th. Rifles, and an excellent game resulted in a draw. The result of the match, can, bow.se ever bardly be taken as a fair criterion of the s respetive merits of the two teams, for the pas sing and combination of the K.O.S.B. was dis tinctly superior to that of their opponents and they had the best of the game throuxbout. The K.O.S.B. soored one goal in the first half, and taiutained their advantage until just before the call of time when the Rifles succeeded in equalizing matters.

div.head: Army of Occupation
div.p: Last Thursday a strong draft of Coldstream Guards left Southampton in the "Soudan" for Egypt, where they will join the third Battalion. Major Skeftington-Smyth was in command of the reinforcements, whose departure was attended by several officers of the Coldstream battalions remaining at home. The same boat is bringing out the 1st Battalion (Alexandra Princess of Wales's Owo) Yorkshire Regiment, the od "19th Foot,' or "Green Howards" Lieut-Col. E. M. Esso in command, and the marching out strength is 21 officers, 830 N.C.O's and men, and 89 w. men and children. One company - Capt. W.B Walker's "C" Company--three officers and 100 N.C.O's and men, has been detailed for twelve months' duty at Cyprus, after wbich it will be relieved by another company from headquarters. The battalion, which leaves Aldershot, witba very high reputation, had a hearty send off.

div.head: Lord Curzon and Parliament.
div.p: SEAT IN LORDS TO BE DISPUTED.
(Gazette's Special Service.)

It is reported that Lord Curzon's right to take bis sent in the House of Lords will be disputed at the opening of Parliament, because De be has failed to establish his right to vote ed at the election of representative Peers for Ireland The matter may be referred to the committee of privileges.

div.head: AMERICAN STOCKS & SHARES.
div.p: (Gazette's Special Service.)

div.head: The Khedive
div.p: His Highness the Khedive will hold his Annual Ball at the Palace of Abdin on the 10th of February. His Highness will return to Cairo from Alexandria tomorrow.

div.head: Al Azhar (The Abdin Incident)
div.p: The unpleasant incident, to which were ferred in Tuesday's issue, apropos of the exclusion of Sheikh Rasi from the Khedive's Coreception at Abdeen Palace does n3t call for any further detailed obeervations. The ovent He was certainly regrettable in that it may CRUSO e certain amount of feeling in the great Uni versity, where, if anywhere, completo barmony should prevail. On the other hand the authorities were left to ohoice in the matter and it was undoubtedly due to the Sheikh's own want of tact that he should have brought himself into such an unpleasant position. The reforun of Al Azhar, on which this inci dent hinges, is one of the great problems apon which the Moslem world appear to be some what, divided. In all cases where religious questions are involved there will over be two parties, those who are in favour of keeping things they are, and those who desire to move with the spirit of the times. Such diver gencies necessarily lead to a great deal of bad blood for there is no more fruitfulsoil for acrimonious hostilities than the "odium theolog icum "His Highness must find himself in great difficulties in his endeavour to reconcile these conflicting elements, but no doubt in course of time with patience and his proverbial powers of persuasion be will bring the parties interest ed to remon. Personally we are not in a position to express any opinion as to the rights and wrongs of the controversy, but what we do feel strongly is that there is an immense deal of wasted power in this great theological seminary It is a thousand pities that some scheme cannot be devised whereby the New University idea cannot be merged in that of Al Athar. All Moslem education must under existing conditions bave a religious basis. Therefore it would be a fatal step, in the present backward condition of the Egyptian people, to concentrate all the elements of progress in order to found New University, thus leaving the venerable and historical Al Azhar to crumble away in neglect and to merely remain as an interesting monument of religious dogma.

div.head: French Deputy On Egyptian Nationalism.
div.p: Mr. Maurice Barrès, the Deputy and Academician, who has just returned from Egypt, has made the following statement to a repre sentative of the "Belair" respecting the Nationalist agitation in that country, a summary of which appeared in our special cable of the 17th. "In the existing condition of affaire no Egyptian could seriously desire the disappear ance of European advisers. If England were to retire, and if she were not succeeded by France or some other European nation, the result would be return to anarchy. This would be felt as intolerable by the fellabs, who are bow acoustomed to justice and equity, which are, if you like, of a relative character, but still very appreciable, if only in the coll setion of taxes. There is, however, a very strong Nationalist sentiment in the hearts of the natives--that is to say their religious feel. ing and their attachment to Islam. Toleration is a natural gift of the Egyptian Mahomedians; but if they considered that offence bad been done to their religion, their feeling against the foreigner might become really active and even dangerous. Thus you see how Egyptian Nationalism is at the same time a very genuine feeling and one without any precise political object."

div.head: Egyptian State Railway Institute
div.p: The Egyptian State Railway Institute was en fete last Thursday evening, being the occasion of the annual ball. Many enjoyable fonctions are promoted by the entertainment committee during the year, but the annual bull is intended to and really does eclipse all. The arrangements were ou an elaborate scale and the comfort of the guests had received the fullest consideration. The approaches were enclosed in Arabic tentage while the balcony was transformed into a sitting out apartment and looked very comfortable decked with bunting and evergreen. The ball room itself was tastefully decorated, indeed better than we have yet seen it with flags and palms, while the chain like array of oriental lanterne lent additional charm to the pro ceedings. Some 200 persons accepted the committee's invitation amongst whom we noticed Macauley Bey and Mr. and Mrs Trevithick. The string band of the King's Own Soottish Borderers played an excellent programme of music under the direction of Sergeant Grimrod which went a long way to make the funotion the nocess it really was. Unfortunately the early morning hours brought wet weather which made the home going decidedly unpleasant over the disgrace. fal state of the surface of the Gbezireb Badran. Messrs. Ison-Cooper and Whittle official. ated as ball room stowards, and their arrangetents were much appreciated.

div.head: Letters to the Editor
div.p: Sir, -The letter which you published yesterfor day, signed by four shareholders of the above Company, suggests a question which in these as difficult times, should be of very general ni interest The Company referred to is, I believe, y constituted under Egyptian Law and your be correspondenta state its object is the purchase ter and improvements of land in Egypt for resale; they further state that the Directors have cht invested in Cyprus sum not expected to on. exceed 2160,000. It appean to me that if the Di Company is an Egyptian one its sphere of action for limited responsibility is confined to Egypt alone, unless it is clearly stated in ita decree of incorporation, that its objects are of wider range than that stated in the letter above referred to. If I am right in this supposition no special resolution of general meetings, ordinary or extraordinary, can change this or subject to Egyptian law of limited responsibility, any transactions undertaken outside this country, and any agch business would be done on the personal responsibility of the directors. It is only right that this should be so, for otherwise any shareholder might find that his noney, which he had subscribed with the understanding that it should be invested in this country, more or less under his own supervision, was being spent in the middle of Ho the desert of Sabarah, or in some equally remote place, from which it might not be ensy to recall it. It is quite probable that some of your readers may be able to give some information on this subject. I only ask for it on general grounds, and not especially er with reference to the company above referred to. I remain, yours truly, Observer.
The Government and the Crisis

TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE." Sir, --It is sincerely to be hoped that the Goveroment will not be induced to listen to the fallacious arguments of our local financiers, who imagine that a loan of two millions will materially relieve the present situation. The situation is clearing of itself, only this process must take time and it will be far clearer afterwards, if the Government does not try to bolster up a false position. Truly yours, PROBITAS. Cairo, January 21

div.head: The Egyptian Estates Limited. (Savoy Hotel Negotiations.)
div.p: The negotiations, which have been continuing of late between the Egyptian Estates Limited and the George Nangovich Hotels Company for the retrocession of the Savoy Hotel at Cairo are being actively pur sued and there is every hope that in a few days' time a satisfactory settlement will be be arrived at, which will free the Egyptian Estates from its embarrassing purchase. The final approbation will be given at an extraordinary general meeting of the shareholders of the George Nungovich Hotels Company, which will be convened at once after the agreement bas been arrived at. If it is decided to sanction the arrangement as to the retrocession of the hotel, no new hotel will be bailt by the company to take the I place of the Savoy Hotel as was originally intended after the hotel had been disposed of to the Egyptian Estates.

div.head: The City and Agricultural Lands of Egypt Limited.
div.p: The "Anglo Egyptian Mail" reports that a certain number of shareholders in the City and Agricultural Lands of Egypt, Limited, bave petitioned the Mixed Tribunals to decree the winding up of the company. They maintain that, notwithstanding the fact that the nominal headquarters of the concern are in London, it is merely an Egyptian joint stock company (société anonyme), which does not fulfil the conditions imposed by Egyptian law to ensure its validity. The Shareholders in I question, who bold some 1,000 shares ask that an official liquidator be appointed, and that the board be dissolved. It will be remembered that the company was formed scarcely a year ago, in order to purobase house property belonging to the Counts de Zogheb, and that the public issuo, which took place recently, was not a success.

div.head: Racing (Ghezireh)
div.p: The Race Course and Stoeplechase Course will be open on Friday 24tb and Banday 26th, Weather permitting.

div.head: Steamer Movements
div.p: The Ellerman lider "Britannia" arrived at Liverpool on Tuesday morning. The Ellerman S.S "Merionethshire" sailed on Tuesday evening for Liverpool direct with a general cargo ipoluding 4,999 bales of cotton and 1980 cases of eggs.

div.head: Cairo Opera Season ("Carmen")
div.p: Mme Magne's "Carmen" was triumph o personality and interpellation : it proved how a really clever gifted artiste can transform herself at will into the most varied and conflict ing parts. In the first act she was the flaunting, bold, hande me factory girl bogdiling her brigadier for the sheer fun of so doing and by the mere contrast ber dovilry to the purity of the pale ooy Micaela. In the lon she was the gipsy, queen among ber sunggling tavern baunters, just decently grateful to the released prisoner, but far more excited by the bold toreror. Theo two acts were triomph. for ber every glance and movement The third at is I venture to believe, impossible for any bat Spaniards or a very, very fow Italians and Mme Magno is neither : and to me there seemed a touch of convention of adaptation, rather, of the part. But the last act again brought out her full powers. Her adoration for Escamillo, her annoyance with Don José and contempt for bis despair, her fright and rage at the danger, and then her death, those were consummate. Two particular features, the quick desperate quiver of her hands as sho retreated from him searching escape in vain, and her scream for Becamillo, heldur entranced, awe-struck, rather. It was a great performance needless to say, the music was AS child's play to her, not a shade of its cold, cynical subtelty escaped her, and she gave the fullest meaning to every intonation. Unusual especially was ber singing when with the chorus, never drowned by it, yet never overpowering it. It was remarkablo. M. Soubayran, was better than usual as Don José, especially at the end. Some of his higher notes were most telling. M. Gorins was also gond, and deserved bis encore for the Toreador,' thongh be forced bis voice a little, it seemed, to obtain the effect. Mlle Talbert was admirably clear and correct M Micaela. The part suited ber and showed that she has an excellent sympathetic voice. The chorns were most adequate. Their acting, as well as their singing, was convincing and showed to better advantage, had their conductor realised more thoroughly the character of Bizet's music. It is a wonder that Carmen musio, torre fascinating every time one bears it, subtlo, unique, daring, absolutely decisive, the production of a real and unusual personality. M. Baron missed the clear, fire and sparkle of it, the crafty, 'diablerie' (the only word) the whole varied strength that distinguishes Bizet from all others. Yet it "went" all the same. The collective power of the singers achieved the result and Madame Magne crownedit.

div.head: Societe Des Concertes
div.p: The only two items in last Sunday's concert which one can mention with equanimity were the Schumann, which was just tolerable, and the ond of the Saint Saens 'deluge' when the violin soloist achieved a brilliant success all too short, slas, was his part, but it was instinct with the dignity and beauty of the music, admirable for tone resonance and absolute certainty. For the rest the orchestra were sheep without a sbepherd, burried headlong through the Bach into the Massenet, and thence into the beginning of the Saint Saëns, without breathing space until the violia solo bawan. Such aliwht continuity and interpretation as appeared was, all through, thanks to the leader of the violins. The conductor evidently was unable to deal with the programme. One would gladly have passed over the whole episode in silence but this attempt of the Society to start organised music in Cairo is so important, that one cannot allow their efforts to be wholly wasted, They have drawn up splendid programmes, and they have procured the services of an admirable orchestra. If the conductor cannot lead the orchestra or interpret the music, he should be left to such pieces and operas as are within bis scope. It w yuld be fatal to encourage throngh mere indul. gence a delusion, the results of which would discourage all music lovers from further attendance or efforts I hear that M. Massio, a famous violinist and musician, is in Cairo, and that he may be induced to conduct at the last four concerts. It is most earnestly to be hoped that he will consent so to do. Since writing this I hear, that M. Massie bas consented to conduct the next concert. It is just possible the date may have to be changed to Wednesday 29th : if that proves necessary, due notice will be given to all subscribers, as well as in the papers, as soon as possible.

div.head: Nile Tourists
div.p: The following passengers left Assiout yesterday by Cook's P.S "Amasis" : Mr. and Mrs. Wallace Tbornyoroft, Mr. and Mrs. Fernand van der Straeten, Mr. Leon Fontaine van der Straeten and the Misses, Mrs. and the Misses E. Quaife. The following passengers left Sbellal this morning by Cook's P.8. "Memnon" : Mr. and Mrs. Max Charlier, Rev. and Mrs. A. W. Gross, Mr. and Mrs. H. L. Groves, Mr. J. C. div.head: Paris-Geneva House
div.p: Mm. Auberge is exhibiting her spring models at the Khedivial Hotel, Alexandria until the 25th inst.

div.head: Personal and Social
div.p: The Barl and Counters of Cromer arrived in London last week from Ardgowan, Greenock, where they had been on a visit to Sir Hugh and Lady Alice Show Stewart The funeral of the late Major-General Sis - Frederic J Goldetnid took place on Wednesday week, at Hollingbourne Chureb, a few miles from Maidstone. Mr. John B. Thayer, Vice President of the Pennsylvania Railway, with party of friends from. Philadelphia arrived at Alexandria by the "Cedrio." Mr. Hall Caine arrived in Egypt yesterday, having closed Groeba Castle, bio Maps house and definitely abandoned his legislativo work in the Isle of Man a member for Ramoy. - - We regret to announce the death of Mrs. Priend, wife of Mr. Astley, P. Priend, the Director of the Water Work Cairo, which ocurred at the Victoria Nursing Home on Wednesday afternoon, following an operation for appendicitis. Mrs. Friend had only beon ill for twelve day. The funeral cortege will leave the Victoria Nursing Home at 8.30 p.m. today. - Rear Admiral Marous Lowther, who died last week at the age of 89, was serving in the "Hastings," stationed in the Mediterranean, wben difficulties arose between the Porte and Mebemet Ali, which resulted in 1840 in the British undertaking operations of the coast of Syria The "Hastings" was ordered to the scene of action, and on September 15 he took part in the capture of Batroon. He was next employed in the distribution of arms to the Maronites, and in October was present in the barge of the "Hastings" at the destruction of mine designed to blow up the eastern fort of Beirut. This brilliant exploit was carried out successfully under the direction of Commander Henry Worth, with the loss of one midshipman of the ship. For bis services during the campaign be received the Syrian medal, and in August, 1844, was promoted to lieutenant. Mrs. Chatterton Adams was "at home" to her friends on Wednesday afternoon in her pretty new flat on the Pyramid Road, very many people taking advantage of their invite tions, and the gathering proving a thoroughly sociable one. The wide balconies were much patronized, the views across the fields of young crops to the distant hills on the Pyramid side and over the city to the guardian Citadel on the other, being particularly fine, even though threatening clouds bung low over the Mokat tams. Among the guests present were Col and Mrs. Duckett, Sir Reginald and Lady Oakes, the Misses Hyde Page, Mrs. Knight, Shakoor Bey with Mrs. Shakoor and their son and daughter, Mrs. and Miss de Bilinski, Miss Johnston, Mr. Melville, Miss Meade, Mr. Dickenson, Mr. and Mrs. Berry, Mr. G. Tomlin son, Mrs. and Mise Devonshire, Mr. Bolland, Mrs. Carver, Mr. Gunter, Miss Mosley, Mr. Campbell, Mr. and Mrs. C. H. Rowlatt, Mrs. and the Miss Moroom, De Beddoo, Mr. and Mrs. Peokett, Mr. Trimen, Miss Morris, Mr. Hylands, Miss Belmore, Mr. and Mrs. Gunn, Mme Mondolfo, Mrs. de Cosso, Mr. and Mrs. Madden, Miss Monde, Mr. A. V. Thomson

div.head: Bulletin De La Bourse
div.p: Jeudi 23 Janvier

Nous assistons décidément à une réaction, qu'avaient fait prévoir d'ailleurs la continuelle bausse des prix soľncidant avec la rareté des affaires. Le recul est-il da à des réalisations ou à une modification quelconque de la situation, voil ce qu'il est difficile de préciser. Cependant, les nouvelles du dehors continuent à être bonnes, le taux privé d'escompte diminue de 4 3 7/8% et les valeurs égyptiennes sont admirablement soutenues tant : Londres qu'à Paris. D'autre part, les récents acbats n'ont pas eu, croyons-nous, assez d'amplenr pour amener deja des réalisations. Il s'agit plutôt sans douto de positions qui venlent profiter de l'amélior tion sensible des prix pour liquider ou s'alléger, mais les acheteurs ayant dispara de la scène, les offres ont déterminé une réaction. C'est done l'invariable jeu de cache cache qui continue dans notre corbeille entre vendeurs et acheteurs. Ainsi l'Obligation ancienne Crédit Foncier rétrograde de 304 à 295 francs. Le fléchisooment de la nouvelle est moins accentué de 259 1/2 à 258 1/2. En revanche, les Lots Tures progressent de 1 franc à 171 à cause de l'approche du tirage du ler Février. Sur le bruit que le coupon serait inférieur celui de l'année posode, l'Agricole est délaissée à 7 11/16, contro 7 23/32 bier. Le pro position faite par un groupe financier d'étendre ses facultés de prêts attend l'approbation du Gouvernement En ce qui concerne la National Bank, le prix avance de 91 1/16 . 21 9/16 en sympathie avec la hausse de Londres 21 5/8 et aussi en raison du manqne de vendeurs sur place. Il n'y a presque pas eu d'affaires. Dans l'ensemble, du resto, les transactions ont été disséminées un peu sur toute la cote mais n'ont eu aucune importance. Aucune veleur n'a été l'objet d'une attention spéciale. Les Privilégiée. Tramways d'Alexandrio fléchissent do 136 à 135, la Banqao d'Athènes de 118 12 118, la Land Bank do 7 9/16 à 7 1/2, l'Urbaine de 8 8/16 31/, l'Unjoo Poncière de 4 7/16 * 48/8, le Crédit Franco Egyptien de 4 3/16 4 1/8, L'Ordinary Khedivial Mail s'améliore, au CODtraire, de 18/- 18/8, lo Comptoir de 9 7/39 25/16, la Building Lande do 1 1/2 a 1 17/39 et la fondateur United do 7/16 & 1/2.
